H0.text: Pressure at which the processes occurred is the difference in quartz formation that results in the various colors of naturally formed quartz.

H1.text: Temperature at which the processes occurred is the difference in quartz formation that results in the different colors of naturally forming quartz.

H2.text: Chemical impurities present as the processes occurred are the difference in quartz formation that results in the different colors of naturally formed quartz.

H3.text: The amount of time passed since the processes occurred is the difference in quartz formation that results in its various natural colors.

A4.text: These color differentiations arise from the presence of impurities which change the molecular orbitals, causing some electronic transitions to take place in the visible spectrum, emitting colored light.

A5.text: Some clear quartz crystals can be treated using heat or gamma irradiation to induce color where it would not otherwise have occurred naturally.

A6.text: Amethyst owes its violet color to irradiation, impurities of iron (Fe3+) and in some cases other transition metals, and the presence of other trace elements, which result in complex crystal lattice substitutions.

A7.text: Exposure to heat partially cancels the irradiation effects and amethyst generally becomes yellow or even green.

A8.text: Rose quartz is formed at very high temperatures of 400–700 °C (752–1,292 °F) in the quartz cores of pegmatites.

A9.text: Its color is due to microscopic inclusions of a fibrous silicate mineral related to dumortierite.

A10.text: This variety derives its color from the presence of aluminium and phosphorus color centers in the crystal structure activated by natural irradiation.

A11.text: Unlike massive rose quartz, pink quartz is photosensitive and subject to fading.

A12.text: Lab-created stones tend to have a more vivid color since impurities common in natural stones are not present in the synthetic stone.

A13.text: Most green quartz (Oro Verde) are also irradiated to achieve the yellow-green color.

A14.text: These gems have slight impurities that act as chromophores and give the stone its color.

A15.text: Trace elements are also used to refer to minor elements in the composition of a rock, or other chemical substance.
